text:
I'm giving this 5 stars even though I changed the recipe somewhat after making it as written the first time. I agree with others that the butter should be cut in half. When I made it as written the first time it was just too greasy for me. The reason I'm keeping the 5 stars is because of all the recipes I've tried from this website THIS is the recipe my family keeps asking me to make. It is simply delicious! Except for cutting the butter in half I keep the ingredients the same. I found that it bakes best covered in foil at 350 degress for the first 30 minutes. Then foil is removed and chicken is basted, basking for another 40 minutes or so until nicely browned. Served with roasted red new potatoes and mixed veggies. Thank you for this wonderful recipe!

text:
FABULICIOUS!  Who knew you could mix honey, mustard, and curry to create such a marvelous flavor? Now I know!  I used boneless, skinless chicken breast, cut the butter in half, used ½ teas. regular salt and ½ teas. garlic salt, doubled the curry powder, and added ¼ teas. cayenne pepper.  I also poked holes in the chicken and let it marinate in the sauce in the fridge for at least an hour before baking it, then put in the oven - 30 minutes covered with aluminum foil, then 20 minutes uncovered.  I paired it with brown rice and garlic roasted asparagus, for an amazing meal.  Bless you Gretchen!

I had to make this chicken three different times just to make sure it was good, and guess what? It was fantastic all three times, one point, is to cover the chicken in the beginning with foil so it won't burn, so just before it is done, uncover it and cook till it is a nice brown. Hope it helps.

text:
Excellent flavor!  My husband asked me to make it TWICE this week!  I made the following modifications based on other reviews and personal preference:

I cut the butter to 1/4 cup, used spicy brown mustard, and upped the curry powder to 1 1/2 teaspoons.  I also added one large clove of garlic, minced, a scant 1/8 teaspoon of cayenne pepper, and half and onion sliced very thin.  I used chicken thighs, and there was enough sauce to do a dozen between two casserole dishes.  I coated them well and baked them covered at 350 degrees for an hour, turning halfway through.  I then removed the foil, basted them again, turned the oven up to 400, and baked them skin side up for an additional 20 minutes.  The skin got nice and brown and crisp.

After baking, there was a lot of fat from the chicken.  I separated the fat and ended up with a nice sauce.  I served the chicken on a bed of long grain/wild rice topped with the sauce - which was really excellent on the rice.  The changes I made resulted in a mildly spicy background flavor that really complimented the sweetness of the honey mustard.  I highly recommend this recipe!

Wow, this was surprisingly delicious.  I used 4 skinless, boneless breasts and cut the butter to 2 tablespoons.  I also eliminated the curry and marinated the chicken for about 4 hours in the sauce mixture.  It was so tender and delicious, everyone was pouring the remaining sauce on their chicken.  I didn't even baste it during cooking and it was great.  Very easy meal- Thanks!

text:
I have been using a modified version of this recipe for more than 20 years.  It is best with chicken thighs.  I have also used turkey breast tenderloins cut into serving pieces and had it turn out very well.  My recipe calls for 1/2 c honey, 1/3 c mustard and 1/4 c butter, 2 t curry powder and no salt.

text:
This recipe has been a family favourite for as long as I can remember.  As much as I hate people who completely change a recipe and then rate it, I'm going to do just that.  I make this with chicken breasts cut up into bite size pieces.  Drop the amount of butter down to about a tablespoon and increase the curry powder to a tablespoon.  Then I add dried fruit (apricots, raisins and craisins are my favorite).  Throw it in oven and bake it until the chicken is cooked.  The mustard/curry/honey sauce gets all gooey and thick and is delicious over rice.

text:
We had this for dinner yesterday and it tasted and looked great! Changes I made to the recipe: I skipped the butter - figured the chicken skin would impart enough oils during cooking. I used dijon mustard instead of yellow for a little more spicyness. Added a teaspoon of garam masala in addition to the curry. I also used a knife and cut little slits in the chicken to ensure more flavor would get into the chicken. Very good .. definitely a keeper!
One thing I should mention is that I'm normally pressed for time in the evening, so I made this in the morning and let the chicken and sauce sit in the fridge until I was ready to put in the oven - this marinating probably helps with the taste as well.

text:
Excellent chicken!!  I did cut the butter in half as recommended, instead of regualr salt, I used Lawry's, and instead of regular mustard, used dijon.  Used a pack of drumsticks instead of a fryer chicken, since that is what I had on-hand.  I dipped each drumstick in the sauce, and placed on a foil lined pan - I like easy clean-up.  Covered the pan with more foil and baked for 30 minutes.  Then uncovered and poured the remaining sauce over the drumsticks and put back (uncovered) in the oven for 45 minutes, basting every 15 minutes.  Served over white rice and poured the yummy cooked up sauce over the rice too.  Both my husband and I loved it!!  He's already planning on trying it out on the grill.  If you like honey-mustard, this is a sure winner!!

text:
I honestly was a little hesitant about using curry since I haven't cooked much with it before but we have found we like it very much in this recipe and it wouldn't be good without it. I mostly always cook with boneless/skinless breasts and it was great. I doubled the sauce recipe but left the butter at 1 stick still because I wouldn't have any natural grease from the skin. We also prefer to use a dijon mustard. Cooked about 9-10 breasts in 9x13 pyrex (kind of piled them in there)at 400 degrees for 1 hour. I turned them over in the sauce 2 or 3 times while cooking. I made myself a note that there wasn't much left the times I have cooked this so I might want to consider doubling again:)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm giving this 3 out of 5 stars as written, four stars with my changes. I used 6 good sized chicken thighs (with bone-in and skin on) which I parboiled for 15 minutes first. I only used 1/2 stick of melted butter since I was decreasing the amount of meat used, but stayed with the 1/2 honey. I did up the amount of curry powder, since a teaspoon is such a small amount for the mild curry I had on hand. I kept the salt in the recipe, but did sprinkle some black pepper on at serving time. I am a fan of curry - all types and flavors from Indian to Irish. Don't expect a high powered spicy sort of curry with this dish unless you use one of the spicier curry blends (like African or Malaysian) that has more hot pepper flavor. With a mild yellow curry blend, combined with the honey and mustard you will get a nice mellow curry dish.   I sliced up some potatoes and carrots and baked them along with the thighs, basting them and the meat every 15 minutes for one hour at 350. I did cover the pan with foil for the first half and then uncovered it, which did the veggies a favor in their cooking, but left the skin on the thighs slightly less crispy than I would have liked.   This is one of those recipes that you should try and get creative with as there are so many things that you can do with the basic guidelines here.

text:
I've wanted to try this recipe for a long time, but when I saw the calorie content for 1 serving (over 1000 calories- are you kidding me!?) I said forget it. Well, I never forgot about this recipe & I thought I'd try it anyway because of the great reviews. I cut the butter down to 1/4 cup & used skinless, bonless chicken breasts.... for all of you who claim your chicken breasts are dry and gross- try this recipe next time you cook the breast. I reduced the cooking time to 45 minutes to ensure that they wouldn't turn out dry. It was so tender & moist! I believe I used a little too much curry though b/c our kitchen smelled like curry for 2 days after I made this lol. This was delicious & a few healthier changes made this dish worth eating.

text:
Thanks to other people's reviews, the version of this I made was truly terrific.  The changes are:  half the butter (1/4 c. butter instead of 1/2 c.), 1-1/2 tsp. curry powder instead of 1 tsp., and the addition of 1/2 tsp. cayenne and 4 minced garlic cloves.  My husband said it was "super yummy," and the "zinginess was great."  (The cayenne is important.)  I wrote my strongest compliment on the printout:  "Make again."  I did, and it was just as terrific the second time.  A keeper for me, and I don't have many of those!

text:
I thought this was an easy, delicious recipe. I did not use a whole chicken, though, as I found this recipe when I was looking for a way to cook up some chicken breasts I had. It was the perfect amount of sauce to cover the 5 large chicken breasts in a 9x13 pan. 

I covered it with aluminum foil and baked it on 375, pulling it out after 40 minutes and flipping the chicken over. I re-foiled it and baked for another 20 minutes. 

For personal preference, I removed the foil and broiled the breasts for 4 minutes, flipped them over and broiled the other side for 4 minutes.

It was perfect. Delicious. Moist. Hmmmmm. My 16 year old son was home and I had him taste it. He loved it. I then had my husban stop working on the yard and taste it. He said it was delicious. My 15 year old (super picky) daughter took a bite, said she did not have enough to really taste it and asked for more... (twice), at which point I knew she liked it. Over all, I was extremely pleased with the chicken.

WHEN I make this again, I will definitely omit the salt because I thought it was too salty. That was the only downfall. I will probably use another 1/2 tsp curry since I really like that flavor.

I loved the underlying sweet flavor of the sauce and turned it into a gravy by adding some cornstarch and cooking it up in the microwave until it was bubbly (3-4 minutes..) The grease from the chicken rose to the surface and I just carefully tipped my glass measuring cup until it drizzled out into the sink and only

text:
WOW! Very easy to prepare, simple ingredients- my kind of recipe.  My kids & hubby loved it.  I did cut the salt & butter to 1/2 of what the recipe called for & doubled the curry powder (our family happens to like curry).  I also took another reviewer's suggestion and lined the bottom of the pan with sliced onion (I highly recommend).   I covered with foil for 1/2 of the cooking time and removed foil to brown chicken for the remainding time while basting every 15 min.  It does make plenty of sauce which is terrific on just plain white basmati rice.  This recipe definitely stays in my recipe box!!

wow! was this an amazing dish or what! Love the flavor and the simplicity of the recipe. followed other reviewers suggestion and reduced the butter by half, cooked with foil on top for 40 mins, later up the oven temp to 250deg C and baked for another 20-30 minutes. I used boneless chicken thighs and they were soooo soft and tender. What I did with the remaining juice was that I added some heavy cream and thicken it with a bit of flour. Dip the chicken in it and absolutely YUM! Oh, and I used Dijon Mustard here. Will make this again! Thanks for sharing the recipe!

text:
Turned out pretty good, my husband and I both enjoyed it. Changed a few things based on other reviews...added 1 1/2 tsp curry powder, 1 clove minced garlic, 1/8 tsp chili powder, and I topped the chicken with sliced onions. I used chili powder instead of cayenne because that's what I had! I also used chicken breasts instead and covered with foil for 30 min, then uncovered for 20. If you feel ambitious like I did, spoon sauce over chicken a few times in the last 20 minutes. I served this with rice and green beans on the side. Will make again!
TIP: Do not taste the unlabelled chili powder to check...my tongue almost fell off!!

text:
This chicken came out very good! Even my two young girls loved it.  My only change for next time will be to start the chicken off skin down for about 30 mins then flip it over and cook skin up for the remanding time.  I really liked how it browned on top, however, the bottom of the chicken had all the flavor since it sat in the juices the whole time with only the top being basted.  If it doesn't brown as well next time when I flip to cook  with both sides in the juice, then I will turn the broiler on for a few to get the caramelized look.

text:
Loved it!  I did make some make some changes though.  Like everyone else i cut the amount of butter to two tablespoons.  Minced 3 garlic cloves and added them on top of the chicken (2 chicken breasts) along with 1/2 onion, sliced.  To the mixture of butter, mustard, etc., i added a teaspoon of chipotle adobo sauce and 1 chiplotle chile- because my bf and i love spicy food and i thought the mixture would be too sweet.The chipotle does not take away  from everything else and it actually didnt make it spicy at all but it does give it a yummy kick. I covered the chicken with aluminium foil for the first 30 minutes, uncovered after and started pouring the mixture every 5-10 mins after for ~35 minutes.  When served the chicken was very juicy and by far the best ive had!!! I served the chicken with red potatoes, carrots, and cauliflower which i also had put in the oven (on a separate pan) and added parsley and 2 teaspoons of the mixture.  Also made rice.  Ill be making this recipe again, loved, loved, loved it! =)

text:
Following Colleen's suggestions, I cut down the butter to 1/4 cup, used Dijon mustard, upped the curry powder just a bit, added a few drips of tabasco sauce and added some minced garlic.  I put my chicken pieces in a zip-lock bag and allowed it to marinate for several hours.  Then I poured the whole thing in a flat casserole dish, covered it and baked it at 350 for over an hour.  Then I took off the lid, increased the oven temp to 400 for another 30 minutes, the chicken pieces turned out very tender, nicely crisped and tasted wonderful.  My teenage son is a very picky eater and he loved it!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My mother wants to introduce curry into her diet because she learned that doctors believe curry and cumin may fend off Alzheimer's (Indian people almost never get Alzheimer's). This is a nice recipe to introduce the flavor of curry to those who may never have tried it before. I used boneless, skinless chicken breasts but didn't marinate mine as suggested by some reviewers. I don't think you need to marinate when baking. I increased curry to one tablespoon and added garlic powder. Left out the onion because I was short on time and cut the butter in half. I bet this sauce would work great for grilling, but I would recommend marinating in that case. Would probably work well with chicken or even fish on the grill. I forgot to put the mustard in the sauce until the last 15 minutes of cooking when I added honey mustard to the pan juices; turned out great. I don't think you can goof this up if you try! My husband really liked the dish. Served it with pine nut couscous but will use rice next time. Nice recipe; thanks.

text:
Excellent with a little less fat!  

Excellent with boneless skinless breasts, with these changes: used 4 breast halves, 1/4 cup butter, half dijon and half plain yellow mustard, 2 tsp curry powder, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, two inch deep square glass pan (the chicken pieces were almost touching).  Cooked at 400 for about 40 min. basting now and then. Sauce never carmelized but the color was good, lots of sauce, chicken was moist, and hubby (who thinks the hates curry) loved it... did not know there was curry in it.  Will do again.

text:
We found this recipe in a cookbook called Cooking Plain and Fancy put together by the Women’s Fellowship of the Upland Brethren in Christ Church 1976 submitted by Jan Harmon and have loved it sense that time.  The recipe in this cookbook is identical to this rendition with the exception that it calls for two fryers.  I hope you enjoyed knowing the lineage of this wonderful dish. A lot of the recipes submitted to this book are Pennsylvanian Dutch.  It would not surprise me that this dish originated in that area of the country.  Thank you for putting it up on-line so that many more people could enjoy it.  Thank You.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great flavor, easy to cook. I cut down the cooking time & the fat. I preheated my oven to 425 degrees. I used 8 bone in, skin on chicken thighs, 3 tbs. of butter & the other ingredients. I removed the skin on 4 thighs, salted/peppered the chicken on both sides. I melted the butter w/the honey & added the mustard & curry powder & poured over chicken. I turned over to coat & baked skin side down covering my dish w/foil. Set timer for 25 minutes. Take out of the oven, turn chicken over while basting & bake for another 20 minutes uncovered. Can broil for 3 minutes if not brown enough. The sauce is great on rice & next time, I might add another tsp. of curry powder to bump up the flavor. Yum!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
AWESOME and FAST!!  Here are the things I did differently:  1.  Used 1/4 cup melted, unsalted butter-  so basically half the butter.  2. Increased the curry to 1 1/2 teaspoonfuls because we like the flavor.  3. Sprinkled my chicken pieces (breasts without skin and legs with skin) with kosher salt and coarse pepper and then let rest until room temp. 4. Put them in a 9X9 dish, covered with sauce, pierced chicken with a knife to increase flavor, sprinkled with cayenne pepper, and covered with foil.  Baked for 30 min then uncovered and cooked until done.  5.  Served with rice the first night.  ROUND TWO:  Make sure to save any extra sauce or consider making extra!  Reheated chicken and sauce the next day and used the sauce as a salad dressing.  MMM warm chicken and dressing over fresh salad greens!!

None
text:
Nice flavor, especially good over couscous, but way too much butter! I'm not normally a low-fat fanatic, so I'm a bit surprised to say I don't think this recipe needs butter at all. If you're using skin-on chicken pieces you'll probably have enough fat rendered from the chicken to enrich the sauce, I don't see the point of adding butter. If you're not using skin-on chicken pieces, you still don't need as much butter as this recipe calls for. Use a couple Tablespoons, at most.

Display Name:
Marcia

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6155224.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I saw this recipe and thought "it can't be that good,  It's just chicken...."   Well, it is!  This is a perfect Gluten Free, Dairy Free (if you use a butter substitute) meal that will please the entire family. My butcher cut up a whole chicken for me and I found some wonderful local honey.  I cut the butter amount down, taking advice from previous reviews, used a Honey Dijon mustard, green curry paste (don't have curry powder), no salt was necessary. Baked at 350 for 30 min and 375 for 30 more min.   I even threw in a sliced onion..  everything came out carmelized beautifully and delicious.  I served the chicken with Jasmine Rice and fresh corn on the cob (baked the last 20 min.with some sauce brushed on, then rolled in foil)

text:
I asked my hubby to rate this and he gave it a 4+.  I followed the recipe exactly.  By not covering the chicken for some part of the cooking time (as some suggested) the chicken skin developed a beautiful golden lacquered look that was very appealing.  Covering was not required because even after 75 minutes in the over, the chicken did not become too dark.  The basting sauce was really tangy and sweet.  This would also be great for just chicken wings.  Next time I'll take the skin off the chicken before cooking.  On the pieces with a whole lot of skin, I hated discarding that wonderful lacquered skin -- but I couldn't bring myself to eat too much of it.  BTW, because some commenters said the chicken was dry, I brined the chicken for a couple hours beforehand.  Viola, juicy chicken every time.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Good base - you can really do anything you want with this but here's how I did it: make the marinade from 2 TBSP mayo, 1/2 cup honey, 1/4 cup dijon mustard, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1/4 tsp onion powder, and 1 TBSP curry powder. We grilled boneless, skinless chicken breasts on the grill (I marinated for 30 min first - the longer, the better!) and we brushed extra sauce on the chicken while grilling. Then I set a little extra sauce to the side and spread a spoonful on each chicken breast just before serving (it melts down on the hot chicken). Delicious sauce, tender moist chicken!

text:
Beautiful recipe!  This is now a regular part of our family menu. Like others, I have modified this a bit. I don't like chicken on bones, so use 3-4 boneless skinless chicken breasts cut into bite sized pieces.  I also only use 1/4 cup butter - and I'm a big fan of butter - but the extra butter just isn't necessary and doesn't improve the flavor at all.  Not using the meat on the bone, it takes less cooking time.  I put foil on for the first ten minutes, baste with pan juices and then 20 minutes with the foil off...and it is done.  Beatifully golden and delicious. Thank you for this recipe!!

text:
FABULOUS! Made this with two large boneless, skinless chicken breast, cut into strips. Still used the same amount of butter in the sauce. Used spicy brown mustard. Also added (as per others suggestions)1/8 tsp cayenne pepper, one clove garlic and about 1/4 cup onions, thinly sliced.  Baked 350, covered for 30 min. Then turned it up to about 410, uncovered and they were finished in 25 min. The extra sauce was great over some steamed white rice. 

Wonderful recipe.

text:
I made this twice and it was a super hit! Here are my slight modifications. I used skinless, boneless chicken breasts and used the recommended amount of butter since I didn't have the grease from the skin. I cut them into small pieces, about 2 inches wide to 4 inches long, and they were a bit dry the first time, so I just cut the breasts in half for cooking the second time and they were succulent. I baked for an hour total at the recommended temp, covering it for the first 30 minutes with aluminum foil, then uncovering it for the last 30 and basting every 15 minutes. Enjoy!!!

text:
Unbelievably good!!! Hubby exclaimed after the first bite, "It's nice!" lol. He then rated it 4 1/2 stars, which is kind of a shock because this was so easy. Dd rated it 8 stars, and I loved it. The taste after the chicken comes out of the oven is spectacular. I halved the honey because I'm used to dh saying he doesn't like very sweet foods when they're normally savoury, but other than that, no changes. I used boned chicken thighs, marinated for 1 hour, covered with foil for 40 mins, and basted every 15 mins after. I cooked until the tips of the chicken turned golden brown. I served this with vegetable chop suey. I lined the bottom of my tray with foil so all the drippings were easy to clean up. Thankyou!! UPDATE: I make this all the time now, using 1/4 cup of honey, 1/4 cup mustard and 1/4 cup of butter (I double the butter if I have extra chicken to 1/2 cup), it's so simple and cheap as I buy the huge tubs of honey and huge bottles of mustard which last me like 6 months and buy blocks of butter and put them in the freezer. I serve this with a cruchy asian salad or vegies. My dd adores it.

text:
This was really, really good; it was easy and kept the chicken moist and flavorful. The only thing that cost a star is that it really didn't need an entire half cup of butter - the sauce eventually had a very oily buttery layer sitting on top of it. I used boneless, skinless breasts, covered the pan with foil, and baked at 350F for about 45 minutes, turning at about 40 minutes and basting occasionally (they were in a pretty small, deep dish). Baked uncovered at 350F for the last half hour or so. Served over rice, and used the pan drippings as a sauce for the rice. Very tasty! Will probably experiment with more spices in the future, too.

text:
This was excellent. My husband and I both enjoyed and it was great for leftovers at work the next day. I hate curry and I used the amount called for in the recipe and it was perfect. It gave it a little bite but didn't overwhelm the sauce.

I used half the amount of butter called for and next time I will use just 2 tablespoons. It really was swimming in butter since the butter seperates from the sauce during baking. I just spooned most of it off, whisked the sauce in the pan and served it over the chicken and rice. Steamed sweet peas made an excellent side item.

The sauce was really good. I will be making this again (probably this week!). I love that it is so good, easy, easy cleanup, and uses items that are easy to keep on hand!

Using boneless/skinless chicken thighs, this wonderful dish only baked for 40 minutes and the flavor was delightful.  As always, I did use a brine on my chicken during the thawing process.  My brine consisted of fresh chopped garlic, S/P, and 2-3 T honey and water.  Per recommedations from others regarding the sauce, I modified by using only 1/4 c butter and 1/4 cup of honey. I used a dijon mustard and also added about 1/2 t of cayenne pepper for some zing.  Bon Appetite!

I absolutely LOVED this recipe! It was so easy and it made for a great dinner with my hubby. I poked holes in the chicken in order to let the sauce soak in and it was really moist when it came out of the oven. I think that next time I might follow Colleen M.'s advice (bake covered at 350 for an hour, turning halfway through. Remove foil, bast again, turn oven to 400 and bake skin-side up for an additional 20 minutes) to get the skin a little crispier. All in all, it was very good and I'm certain I'll make it again.

text:
This chicken is outstanding and so easy to prepare!!  I had to use 1/2 regular mustard 1/2 Dijon because I ran out of regular. This made more than enough to cover 2 large boneless chicken breasts and 4 bone-in thighs. I kept the chicken covered until the last 15 minutes and it came out a gorgeous color, not burnt-looking at all. The meat was not spicy AT ALL so if you enjoy a little kick, I'd recommend using the spicy curry powder, possibly adding a little Tabasco to the mix. My picky mother-in-law actually complemented this chicken several times -  I will definitely make this again!

text:
This was good...I made it a little healthier. I used chicken breast, and I browned them on the skillet with a little olive oil and minced garlic. Added salt & pepper, added some oregano, and basil for a savory flavor. I then made the marinade with the honey and regular mustard. I saw that Dijion mustard had a more sweet flavor/aroma. I then added a couple of shakes of paprika and cayanne as someone else suggested. I omitted the butter all together. I flipped it twice, and before it was done I added some cornstarch & water directly to the dish in the oven & it thickened the sauce up, and put this over the chicken when I plated it. Thanks!

text:
My entire family ate this up!!  My 4 & 2 year old cleaned their plates.  I used 6 chicken legs, about 1&1/2 lbs, and had the right amount of sauce to just about cover the chicken.  I baked at 400 and turned every 25 minutes three times and the sauce nicly glazed the chicken.  Based on other reviews I halved the butter.  I put two large potatoes in the oven to bake at the same time as the chicken and dinner couldn't have been easier to prepare.  I think next time, and there will be many next times, I will line my pan with renolds release to make clean up just as easy.  I think this would work well on the grill if it was marinated first.  THANK YOU GRETCHEN!!  For an extra kick try using red curry powder.  Very nice!!

All three kids, 14, 12 & 10 clean their plates and ask for more and I scraped every last stuck on drop of the sauce up after dinner I thought I should just sit down and write my review. text:
This was MUCH better than I imagined it would be. After reading the reviews, I used boneless, skinless chicken breasts, and reduced the salt to 3/4 tsp and reduced the butter to 1/4 cup, and kept the other ingredient amounts as written. I did use sourwood honey, as that's what I had.  Baked @ 375 for about 40 min.,and covered after about 20 min. Then, I turned on the broiler and broiled each side of the chicken. Be sure to spoon some sauce over each piece of chicken before serving... you don't want any of that good sauce to go to waste! HaHa!
Thanks for posting the recipe!!

Absolutely loved this recipe. Read some of the reviews and only added dry roasted garlic about 2 tsp to the mixture. Baked at 350F for 1 hour turning after 30 minutes and basting 2X in 2nd 30 minutes. Removed foil, increased temp to 375F, turned skin side up and baked another 20 minutes. Perfectly crisped and sauce reduced to great consistency for pouring over chicken on a bed of basmati rice. Will definitely use this one again!

userID:
3439691
Display Name:
Alison Shafer
isPro:

followersCount:
1

madeRecipesCount:
4

34

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe as written a few times and it is great!!! As with most recipes that I love, once I am comfortable with the dish I like to tweak it a bit to make it my own. Here are the changes that I have made and found to be wonderful...
1. I use chicken breast, parboiled in chicken broth or sauteed in butter (depending on my mood) then drained. This prevents the flavor and consistency of the sauce from being diluted by the chicken juices.
2. Mix together 1/2 cup of melted butter, just under 1/2 cup of honey, and just under 1/4 cup of mustard. 2 tsp curry powder (as others have suggested) 1/2 tsp garam masala, 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper and 1/2 tsp salt.
3. Pour the mixture over the chicken in a casserole dish, cover and bake 10-15 min til sauce gets nice and sticky.
4. Spoon over rice and top with crushed walnuts and dried cranberries.

***I recently served this with butternut squash sauteed in butter and sprinkled with brown sugar.

text:
Wow. Such simple ingredients and a great taste! Giving four stars because I did modify the recipe a bit as per others' comments. Did 1/4 cup butter, 1/4 cup honey and 1/2 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp garlic salt. I used Madras curry powder (I'm Indian myself) dijon mustard, and I didn't make a whole chicken, I used chicken tenders. Baking time was 30 min uncovered, 15 min covered. Then the chicken was still a bit watery, I transferred the chicken and the drippings into a pan and fried it until the water dried up and the chicken was a bit browned on both sides. Superb. I do feel like the recipe is missing a tang, perhaps the next time I make it I'll sprinkle some lemon juice on top. As far as the curry flavor, I felt like the honey and mustard gave most of the flavor and the curry was a smoky backdrop.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-05-31T23:20:33.963

text:
Super easy to make and extremely tasty! Hubby and I enjoyed this with steamed garlic and his 'smashed' taters. I used cumin instead of curry powder (didn't have any!) and it was definitely a great substitute. WILL make again. Didn't chop the chicken into pieces though, I just cut through the breast portion and flattened it out a bit. I baked it in a round Pampered Chef baking stone and ladled the 'sauce' over top every 15-20 minutes or so. Absolutely a staple in our house now.

userID:
4500633
Display Name:
Jackie.d.c.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our family favorite! The first few times I made this exactly as the recipe directed and it was really good. Now I made it with a few adjustments and its AMAZING. First I use 2.5 tsp of curry and I totally eliminate the butter and in its place I use 2 tbs of olive oil. In addition I crumble up one of these 4oz tubes of goat cheese with herbs, usually the brand President, and add it to the mix. I add my clean/washed chicken to the mix of curry, salt, honey, mustard (I use Grey Poupon Dijon) and goat cheese and put in all in a Ziploc bag and let it marinate overnight. Then I put all the ingredients in Pyrex dish and add cubes of Feta cheese, about 100grams. I make sure to poke the feta down into the sauce so they don't burn. I like to have enough of the honey-mustard mixture so that the chicken is almost covered and there is enough sauce to add on top of the rice or couscous when serving.

Display Name:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This chicken was excellent!  As with other reviewers, I made the following modifications: 1.  Used boneless, skinless chicken thighs 2.  Cut the butter to two tablespoons 3.  Cut the salt to 1/2 teaspoon. I put the marinade on the chicken in a baking dish the morning I was going to use it.  I let it marinade all day and then baked it at 375 covered with aluminum foil for 20 minutes.  Then I basted the chicken and removed the foil, cooking the chicken for another 20 minutes.  I basted it again a second time about 10 minutes before it was done.  The chicken was super moist and flavorful and delicious!  My preschooler loved it and asked for more.

country:
None
text:
Good weeknight recipe and easy to prepare. There are only two of us, so I used a package of four chicken thighs.  We like a little zing, so I used half dijon and half grainy mustard.  I also used half butter and half olive oil to cut down at least a little on the fat, and was heavy handed with the curry because we like it alot.  Served with heirloom wild rice blend and steamed green beans.  Will probably put into the dinner rotation once or twice a month.  Also, this is a great recipe to play with and experiment with the flavors in the glaze.  I think I might add some chopped, fresh thai basil next time.  I think the basil and the curry will compliment each other and make it even more "thai-like" in taste.  Thanks!

text:
This really was the best chicken I've ever made.  Everyone at dinner couldn't stop talking about how flavorful and moist this was.  I used 2 large bone-in breasts and 6 large bone-in thighs since these are our favorite parts of the chicken, and left the skin on.  I think the bone and skin are essential to this recipe's success. The meat literally just fell off the bone when done. The basting sauce is simple to throw together and gives the most wonderful taste to the finished product.  I think I will try this on chicken wings next.  I wouldn't change anything in this recipe.

text:
I did this out on the grill and it was absolutely awesome! I did as others suggested and only used 1/4 cup butter, and I increased the curry to 1 tablespoon, I also used chicken legs. I added some garlic powder,paprika,and a teaspoon of sesame seeds.  I wrapped it all in heavy duty foil on the outside and used my non-stick foil to make a tray with sides to hold my chicken legs and sauce for the inside of my packet. I wrapped it up tight and cooked then on low heat for a half hour, then cranked the heat to a medium level and opened the foil.  I flipped the legs 2 times and basted the sauce on them for about another 35 minutes ( until the sauce was thinkend nicely and the chicken was browned) and they turned out incredible. TRY THIS RECIPE, you will not be disappointed.

great flavor and smell! I just cut the butter in half-the extra is only adding useless calories and fat. The thing I really like about this marinade is it's thick enough to actually stick to the marinade while sitting instead of just dripping off the sides. ********UPDATE******** There was a bunch of leftover marinade one the bottom of the dish after this came out of the oven, so I put it in a pan, added about a tbsp plus 1 tsp of cornstarch mixed with about 2 tbsp water and added to marinade to make a slightly thick, almost barbecue sauce texture to dip it in-it was absolutely fabulous!

This is very good.  I give it a four-star for two reasons:  1.)We're not "WOW!  This is fantastic!" about it, but everyone gobbles it up (13 and 11 yr old included).  2.)I make a few changes, so that alone merits less than 5 stars.  Changes: Half the butter, double+ the curry powder, a wee bit more mustard, a generous spoonful of minced garlic, and perhaps a 1/2 tsp of cayenne.  I taste and adjust as I go along.  For note, I cover for first 30 minutes and uncover for last 10-15; although I have only made this with thighs - white meat might need adjusting (and I have a gas oven, not electric - also a probable factor).  This goes into my regular rotation box, but isn't a "wow" five-star.  More of a good, solid meal that satisfies.

userID:

Display Name:
mermaid
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Way too much fat when using skin on chicken,and cut up chicken certainly doesn't take 75 minutes to cook through at 350 degrees. Either use skinned chicken and cut back on the butter (just a couple of tablespoons will do) or omit the butter altogether if using skin on chicken. I prefer skin and deboned chicken breasts for this recipe, and just a small amount of butter for flavor. I've even used just a couple of tablespoons of olive oil instead of the butter. Cook the breasts for no more than 30 minutes. They should be cooked through in that length of time at 375 degrees, but always use a meat thermometer to check for doneness. Don't rely solely on time and temperature.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-01-06T12:29:20.93

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been a family fav for years. I do use a bit more curry, and I use breasts. 
 
It's also an awesome chicken recipe to use  for chicken salad--combine chilled and chopped chicken with mayo, green onion, diced red onion, diced apple, quartered grapes and golden rasins. I like to bake the chicken the night before so the flavors get more intense, then chop it and mix the salad together in the morning, again to let the flavors blend.  

Serve on bread for a sandwich or in small lettuce or Belgian endive leafs for a savory/sweet appetizer.

userID:
2081618
Display Name:
SIRMIROM
isPro:
False

0

39
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I not only halved the butter, but used butter-flavor margarine instead, and even substituted some of THAT with olive oil. Just to make the melting easier, I ended up making all the sauce ingredients in a saucepan, so they all melded together nicely.

I baked two cut up chickens with the sauce (it made a LOT of sauce) at about 375 for 45 minutes, then uncovered, basted with a bit of reserved sauce, and they were done in about another 20 minutes. I ran the broiler for a couple extra minutes to get them brown and pretty.

The sauce is fatty enough that you can remove the skin from the chicken pieces with impunity. Even the white meat stayed fairly moist.

I like curry, and I like honey mustard, but I didn't ADORE this particular combination. I think chopped onions would have enhanced it. My guests and husband were happy though. Recommend mashed potatoes or rice or something on the side to help soak up the extra juices. Am looking forward to the leftovers making great chicken salad.

made a combo of the suggestions here. i used 3 boneless, skinless breasts. i reduced the margarine by half and used smart balance. i used dijon instead of regular mustard. i used one teaspoon of curry and 1/2 a teaspoon of garam masala. i omitted the salt. baked 30 mins covered with foil, then 20 uncovered. it was fab! served with brown rice and a salad.

This turned out great! I learned out to cut a whole chicken. Then I made the sauce, using 1 cup of honey 9i thought was the perfect solution for the not enough honet problem people have been referring too. I figured two cups would be too much. I added already cut adried onions, and alrewady minced garlic gloves, 1/4 water, some vegtable flakes, almost 1 cup of spicy mustard. (I was running out), and 2 tablesppons of curry powder. It turned out perfectly! Poured over the chicken, and let it bake under foil, as suggested. What I recommend with the chicken is rice. A good way to do it is add french onion soup, I used brown rice, and like 1/2 cup of water. I turned out good, if only I didn't burn it! Remember keeop an eye on your rice, and stir continuly! Honey chicken sauce taste good with rice! Thanks for thev recipe! It was delious!

I just made this tonight and it was really good, both my kids, 4 and 7 year old, gave it two thumbs up! The only thing i changed was that i added more curry powder and will probably add 3 tsp next time. I think you could decrease the amount of the butter by 1/2, making it a little bit healthier. The long cooking time keeps this recipe in "my days off" list of supper ideas though.

text:
I just made it last night and it's not exactly what I expected but it is very tasty. I used the recipe changes the other reviewer did-cut the butter in half, more curry, and added onions. Its very sweet. I used dijon mustard cause thats all i had so I think thats why it was a tad more sweet. Id probably use spicy brown next time and add a lot more onions to add some more flavor because the curry is very potent. This might even be good with a little coconut milk! The chicken was juicy and I paired it with brown rice and green beans. I also had a little bit of left over sauce to use again. I put it on some Garbanzo beans with the chicken and that was really good! Personally, I felt like it needed a little something extra not sure what but overrall yummy and totally easy!!

This was DELICIOUS!! My husband and I really REALLY liked this dish. I can't believe how it easy it was. I followed the recipe exactly except I doubled the amount of curry powder. Since I cook for just my husband and myself, I used 2 piece of boneless skinless chicken breast. I put them in a baking dish, poured the sauce on top, covered it, and baked it for 30 minutes. I did take it out after 15 minutes to baste the chicken to prevent dryness. When it was done it was incredibly moist and tasty. I highly recommend this recipe!!

None
text:
Excellent!  This chicken was beautiful and delicious.  Served with white rice and leftover sauce (after skimming the oil off the top of sauce.)  As we prefer strong-flavored food, I made the following changes as suggested by others:

Used 2 chicken leg quarters, skin on
Baked covered for 40 minutes at 350 degrees
Uncovered and baked 35 minutes at 400 degrees
Saved half the sauce for use when basting
Used half the margarine
Doubled the curry powder
Used spicy brown mustard
Used Creole seasoning instead of salt, and sprinkled half of it directly on the chicken before covering in sauce.  Put the remaining seasoning into the sauce.

Made this way, I wouldn't change a thing and will definitely make this again!

text:
My family LOVED this recipe!!!  I tend to make chicken a lot and they groaned when they heard we were having it again, but they raved about this recipe and gobbled it up.  My son smelled the curry while baking and imediately had issues (he doesn't like it) but ended up having seconds. Very easy to make.  I did cut the butter by half, and I added a tsp. of chopped garlic and used Dijon mustard.  I baked it covered at 350 for 30 minutes and uncovered for about 40 minutes more, basting every 15 min during the uncovered time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm often one ingredient shy of a recipe, and this time was no exception.  I had no honey, but noticed in a similar recipe, a woman had used corn syrup as a substitute, and it worked, so I altered this recipe a bit.  I did have some honey mustard in the cupboard, so I used:  1/4 cup corn syrup, 1/3 cup honey mustard, 2 tsp curry powder, two dashes cayanne pepper, 1 tsp salt, and about 6 tbsp of butter.  It was really good, but next time I would double all of the above, and reserve half the sauce to pour over at the midway point.  I also used 4 skinless boneless chicken breasts, and the timing was fine.  Put this over white rice, and double the sauce.

text:
I really liked this dish.  I'm not sure what I like more - the wonderful taste or how easy it was to make!  I used chicken legs and didn't think it was greasy like some other reviewers.  As soon as it was done, I took the chicken out of the pan and onto a serving dish.  If you leave the chicken in the pan, it will become greasy.  I added a little bit of the pan drippings to my rice and that was delicious!  My husband does not like mustard or curry powder in his dishes, so I didn't say a word about this having BOTH!  He could not tell and liked the chicken.

text:
Loved this recipe!  I only used 2 leg quarters (2 thighs, 2 legs).  I slashed and stabbed the chicken before putting it in the casserole dish to make sure th marinade would permeate the chicken.  I used about 3 pats of butter instead of the recommended amount and used maybe a tablespoon of mustard.  I also  fried a sliced onion and added it to the marinade.  I basted the chicken a few times while it was cooking and raised the temp to 400.  It was done in an hour and tasted so good with basmati rice and cinnamon, honey and brown sugar flavored carrots!!!  My picky 2 year old loved the rice with gravy mixed in and asked for more.  I think this would even taste great with wings too!

This was wonderful and turned out very well with a few changes.  I used boneless thighs and decided to cook this on the stove top. I made this with bone in thighs and it was really, really good ( my husband ate 3 pieces). The only thing I did different is added  fresh garlic and doubled the recipe for the sauce. I coated the chicken with 1/2 the sauce and baked covered for 45 min, then brushed on the other  1/2 every 10 min until cooked and the tops were crispy. Will for sure make this again!

Very good.  It's a versatile recipe that I will be playing with next time I make it.  1/4 cup butter is plenty as other reviewers have noted.  I will double the curry because we love curry and also add a couple of cloves of crushed garlic.  Sprinkle green onions on top.

Melicious

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1069772.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  Its fast and easy, and I like making it for potlucks or guests, or just the family.  It also doubles and triples well. These are my changes: 
1. Instead of adding salt, I brine my chicken in salt water a couple hours ahead of time (this helps the chicken retain some of its juices better).
2. I use some of the butter and brown the chicken on the stove first (takes 10-20 minutes of cook time, but reduces the bake time and makes for more tender chicken)
3. I bake the chicken for 40-50 minutes, covering part time, and uncovering for the last 20 minutes.
4. I mix up the sauce in the fry pan after I remove the chicken pieces, then pour it over the chicken pieces in the baking pan.
5. I use 3 pounds of drumsticks in place of chicken pieces.

text:
I cooked this last night and wow!!!  I did find a couple of the reviews helpful. I halved the butter and the honey. used creole mustard, Louisiana spice, a dash of cayenne, and garlic.  I cooked the chicken as suggested covered for thirty minutes and then removed the chicken.  i added four large sweet potatoes sliced thick and cut in half spread across the pan and then put the chicken in and among the potatoes. Not a morsel of anything left!   My daughter used bread to clean the dish!!!!  So with this in mind, I will double the sauce next time and cook two 9x13 pans of this.  This is truly one of the easiest and best chicken dishes I have ever cooked and eaten!  Rave reviews from all.  I actually can't wait to cook it again….and again… Thank you Gretchen!

text:
Rich flavor with few ingredients.  My family enjoyed it.  I halved the butter portion, doubled the curry, and added pepper, garlic, onions, and seasoning salt to satisfy our palate.   Marinated thighs, drumsticks, and wings in the honey sauce for 2 hours, then baked covered with foil for first 30 minutes, then uncovered for the rest as recommended by some raters.  However, in the pursuit of the perfect brown finish, I prolonged the bakery time, and unfortunately over cooked it.  Family still enjoyed the flavors without even realizing the  over baked state of the chicken like I did.  I will try it without the foil next time for a more tender quality to final chicken product.  Thanks!

Display Name:
Muscle Jock Chef

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1440020.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This really is a simple and good recipe and just like the other reviewers said you would need to add more curry than required or you would just have honey mustard sauce... I also think you do need to add cyannne pepper and most def decrease the butter.. In fact you can substitute the better for EVOO. Add some garlic powder & slice onions over the chicken before pouring the sauce over it.. Cover with foil for the first 40 minutes of baking .. then take the cover off turn up temperature to 400 degrees .... OMG the taste is great I did this over to big leg quarters.. The next time I do it I will let the chicken marinate in the sauce in a ziplock bag overnight. Also poke holes in the chicken for a full marinade . I also suggest using a Dijon mustard or Spicy mustard ... just so you will not have THE TYPICAL HONEY MUSTARD flavor.. Also adding Gram Marsala will put a good twist on it.

text:
My family loved!!! this recipes..it went over really well in our home and we were all scrambling for the left over pieces..now I used chicken wings instead b/c the market doesn't sale what i needed but they were still a hit..I simply seasoned before hand with salt, pepper, onion & garlic powder..let that sit for a while..I then made the sauce but kind of free handed b/c I knew I would need/want extra..so I kept the amount of butter the same (1/2c), but used 3/4c honey, 1/4 +1/8 (half of 1/4c) mustard, a sprinkle or two of fine salt and used 2tbs curry, plus a sprinkle (eyeball) onion & garlic powder and a sprinkle of cayenne pepper..brought all these to a boil (which also thickened as it cooled)..I basted the chicken, covered it and put it in the oven to bake..after about 45mins i took off the foil, basted my wings and continued to baste till they were done and I was out of sauce..plus It made its own juice in the bottom 
:-))..thanks to the other reviewers for their comments..it helped..

text:
I made this with boneless skinless chicken thighs.  Instead of curry powered I added about a tablespoon of green curry paste, I also replaced half the amount of honey with agave nectar….The butter I kept at half a cup and then just added some sea salt and a squirt of dijon mustard (I didn't have any mustard powered).

The result was amazing…..I also poured off the sauce from the pan and reduced on the stove for about 10 minutes then drizzled the thick sauce (it looked like caramel) over the chicken before I served it….

There was no leftovers and I can't wait to make it again!

text:
This was so so good!  I used boneless, skinless thighs and baked them at 300 for 35 minutes covered, then took the foil off, raised it to 325 and cooked them another 35 minutes. I took other people's advice and used only 1/4 cup butter, which was perfect- not greasy at all- and added about 1/4 cup minced fresh red onion (only because I had it and needed to use it) My son didn't like it because he's picky so I think next time I might add some spice.  Next time I also might try using dijon instead of yellow mustard (Only because I'm compelled to change recipes!)  It went perfectly with basmati rice and steamed broccoli, using the sauce like a gravy.

I read the reviews first (ofcourse)and cut the butter and salt by half. Everything else I kept the same. Excellent! For two large bone-in breasts, I used 2 TBs butter, honey, and mustard, and 1/2 tsp hot curry. Well-seasoned with s&p, I baked them covered for 1 1/4 hrs, then uncovered with the glaze for another 45 min. Fall-off-the-bone tender and very moist. Definitely a keeper.

text:
I really liked this - I cut the 'marinade' in half (didn't realize I only had 1/2 a stick of butter left!) and used 3 boneless skinless chicken breasts.  Served it with brown rice and crescent rolls.  I tossed some milk and cornstarch into the sauce after the chicken was done to thicken it up and poured it over the chicken and rice.  My husband unfortunately was not a fan, which is disappointing because I thought it was very good!  The reason I didn't rate this 5 stars is because it didn't blow me away, and it won't become a staple in our household, but I think it was definitely worth making and I personally would love to have it again.

userID:
6037542
Display Name:
ali-oop
isPro:

9

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/565147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this recipe was delicious and easy. Per the other reviews I cut the butter in half and it was more than enough. I also added more like a Tbls. of curry. I think next time I would add even more curry! I personally think you can't go wrong with curry. I used drumsticks for this recipe (skin removed) and I did let the chicken marinate for a few hours prior to baking. I always cut a few slits into my chicken when marinating. I baked covered for 40 minutes and then uncovered for approx. 30-35 minutes basting and turning the chicken every so often. The chicken came out perfectly moist and so flavorful. I served with basmati rice and a carrot and pea medley with some Middle Eastern spices. My husband and I loved it! We even have enough for lunch tomorrow! Thanks Gretchen, for a simple and yummy recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Where to begin.  I chose this recipe because I had all the ingredients.  While it was cooking, my husband began asking when it would be done.  He LOVED the smell.  My son in law ate it and loved it and he is so picky.  My daughter loved it.  I loved it.  I only had five chicken thighs to work with.  I cut the butter in half as others suggested.  I covered the pan with foil for thirty minutes, then let it cook uncovered the rest of the time.  I was surprised how it browned up so nicely.  Basting with the juices is definitely key.   I served it with brown rice and steamed fresh broccoli from the garden.  This is definitely a keeper!  Just an FYI... days later and family members are STILL commenting on how good this was.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! YUM! This was super delicious and easy to make. I followed this recipe using 4 skinless chicken breast halves and only 2 tablespoon of Smart Balance butter. Also, since I didn't have any curry powder, I used about 2 tablespoon combination of chili powder, cumin and coriander. I marinated the chicken for 3 hours then baked in a closed foil for 30 mins. The remaining 40 mins, I opened the foil, added chopped carrots and potatoes then basted the chicken and veges every 15 mins. The chicken came out very tender and flavorful. I poured the sauce over the chicken and veges and served this with brown rice. I would definitely make this again and would recommend it to anyone. Thank you Gretchen for sharing this wonderful recipe. =)

text:
This is one of my favorite recipes on this site!  I use chicken breasts rather than whole chicken pieces.  As per previous reviews, I cut the amount of butter in half.  I also usually don't have curry, so I substitute an equal amount of cumin and coriander with a dash of cinnamon.  Everything else is the same.  I bake it covered for 45 minutes and then uncover for the remaining baking time.  My husband and kids love this.

text:
Excellent - better than I expected. I'm glad that there were so many good reviews to temp me to try it. I used about 1/4c butter, 1/4c honey, 2 TBSP mustard, dash of apple cider vinegar, season salt, some mustard powder, some garlic powder and the curry. I thought it was the right amount for 1 whole chicken, quartered. Also, I made it up at lunch time then put it in for dinner, so it marinated some - that probably didn't hurt. Yum! I'll make it again for sure - and may even try the original recipe exactly.

text:
This chicken recipe was GREAT! I had 4 leg/thigh pieces, halved the sauce recipe, and marinated it in the fridge for a day and a night. In baking, I covered the chicken for the first 30 minutes and uncovered it for 25 minutes more, basting a few times. The chicken browned beatifully and the flavor was wild! I didn't have curry powder so I put together my own curry blend, mainly cumin and turmeric with dashes of chili powder, cardemon, cinnamon, black pepper, mustard, corriander, and ginger. Thank you Gretchen!

My husband loved this recipe. I doubled the curry, and used only about 1 Tbs of butter. I also used honey dijon mustard. text:
This is an awesome recipe.  Really simple to make and tastes awesome.  I used boneless skinless chicken breast, cooked at 350 for 30 mins and it was done perfectly.  I think I used a smaller/deeper dish than instructed as there was no need to baste (added to easiness). I served the finished dish over white basmati rice with steamed carrots.  The sauce was really nice over the carrots too.  I think I will add some to the dish in the oven next time.  The other small change I may make next time is add a little flour or cornstarch so the final sauce is thickened a little bit.  Definitely going to make it into my regular rotation.  Thanks Gretchen!

This recipe is wonderful.  It's in my favorites list.  I followed the advice of others and reduced the amount of butter.  I also seasoned the chicken (I used boneless, skinless breasts) with Beau Monde seasoning.  Honestly, I don't work or have any stock in Spice Islands, but everyone should have Beau Monde close at hand as a salt substitute, or seasoning.  I used Dijon mustard, as I much prefer it over yellow mustard.  Compliments to the chef!

Sorry, but we just did not care for this.  I was really disappointed - the sauce was really tasty before I added it to the chicken and baked it.  Once it was cooked, however, not so good!  In all fairness, I have never cooked with curry, so maybe that was it.  I'm surprised though because I like Indian food and I like all of the spices that comprise curry powder.  Anyway, I was almost embarrassed to serve this meal because I knew nobody would like it - I mean I wasn't even willing to eat it.  I served it with BBQ sauce on the side and that helped get it down. Three stars for ease of preparation and to compensate for the fact that maybe we just don't like curry.

Would give this 4.5 star if possible - used the other reviewers advice and halved the amount of butter.  Also mixed both dijon and spicy brown mustard (most reviewers used one or the other instead of prepared mustard).... another modification from other reviewers was to increase the amount of curry and add seasoning/garlic salt. text:
Wow!  My entire family liked this recipe.  That's pretty rare.  I had to modify the cooking because I didn't have an hour and a quarter to bake it.  So I used boneless skinless chicken breasts, seared them and then fried them to almost done in a skillet, poured on the sauce, and simmered them covered for about 20 minutes.  That was probably a little too long, the sauce nearly caramelized, but it was oh!so-good! I did make a couple sauce substitutions, as well: garlic salt instead of plain, and spicy brown mustard instead of yellow.  Thank you, Gretchen, for sharing this.  It got an enthusiastic "Make this again!"

Great recipe for chicken breast.  I made a few changes/additions due to personal taste.  I used a little olive oil instead of butter, added cayenne pepper, a touch of brown sugar, and black pepper.  I marinated the chicken all day, cooked it covered for 20 minutes and uncovered for 20 minutes.  The outcome was a deliciously flavored moist chicken breast.  Thanks so much for the recipe.

text:
Very good recipe. I baked in a casserole 7 chicken thighs, marinated 1 hour in the honey sauce, on a bed of slices of potato, carrot and onion  (30 min closed and 45 min open). I made the sauce without the butter (and 2 tsp of curry) with great success (thighs have already a lot of grease). The baked chicken had a nice color and pleasant taste. BTW, I added a pinch of cayenne in each thigh for an additional kick.

text:
This chicken has such a great flavor.
I used breasts cut into small pieces and fried them, rather than baked, over medium high heat until chicken was cooked through.  I followed the recipe exactly on measurments and it was perfect!  I did add 1/2 tsp of garlic salt and 1/4 small chopped onion.  I used brown mustard instead of regular mustard in hopes to avoid the bitter taste I feared regular would create. I did not have extra sauce left over after frying. My husband does not like mustard and did not care for this dish.  I do like mustard and I loved this one!!  I served it over chicken rice.  It is just as good reheated.

text:
I scaled back the butter like the other reviewers, but also threw in a tsp of cayenne pepper and 2 tbsp of sweet onion mustard. I roasted at 350 for 1 hour, had it covered for only 30 minutes of that, then at 400 for 30 min and 425 for 10 min, to get it crispy. I basted it every 30 minutes and poured a little of the uncooked, thick honey mix over the chicken right before serving. It was yummy!

text:
I am rating this one for my mom.  I have not tried making it yet, although I did get to eat a little of my mom's; it was awesome.  I read a review by "Erin" (which is also my name, incidentally) on how curry and cumin are thought to prevent Alzheimer's, as Indian people almost never get it.  I emailed this recipe to my mom, whose mother had recentally passed (and had Alzheimer's), and suggested she try it.  I didn't really think she was going to...I also thought she would scoff at the cumin and curry being able to prevent Alzheimer's.  Instead, she said she had indeed heard that before, and she ended up making a bunch of this chicken, and inviting friends over for dinner.  My mom said that my father made fun of her for making so much chicken but that she ended up only having a tiny bit left over, for me; everyone loved it and it was a huge hit.  My mom still raves about this one, and her friends told her to thank me for recommending it.  I know that she mentioned reading reviews beforehand and making adjustments based on others suggestions...for instance, I know she just used boneless, skinless, chicken breasts.  Thanks for the recipe, I'm looking forward to making it myself!

text:
I made this using slightly less butter, but the other ingredients to a tee. I also used a whole chicken that I cut into pieces. I had full intentions of cooking it the same day I had prepared the ingredients, but alas, that did not happen. So I put the chicken in the pan, poured the stuff over everything, covered it and let it marinade for almost 24 hours. It was a nice change from the normal chicken, and the leftovers made GREAT tacos and quesidilas [spelling]. The only thing I disliked is the butter aspect. I still feel it was too much even though I reduced it, so I'll have to try it again and see how it works.

I used chicken drumsticks since that is what I had available. I used the recipe exactly as stated otherwise. There was more than enough sauce to cover the 8 drumsticks that I had. I put them in a baking dish and the sauce seemed to get pretty runny. They didn't have to cook as long (about 45 min at 350) The flavor didn't get into the chicken as much as I'd like. I may try it again and marinate it for awhile first. But no one complained...all were gone!! Thanks...

text:
I used half a stick of butter, doubled the mustard (3 varieties) and had no honey, so used real maple syrup instead (probably used double the amount called for but I wanted lots of sauce). My husband loved it and the kids ate all theirs! Forgot the salt but it was great. Probably will use syrup from now on since honey is more expensive where we live.
I served it with sweet potatoes, carrots, and zucchini pan-fried. Saved the extra sauce and used it on sticky rice for lunch.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe. I took the advice of other reviewers and added 1 tsp of garlic and chopped onions. I also upped the curry powder to 2 tsp. I melted a boullioun cube with half the butter and covered it with foil until the last 20 minutes. You do need to baste this chicken.

The chicken was delicious. My family really loved it. I'll be making this again.

Tip: If you make the sauce as it is, it makes a wonderful dip for fried chicken nuggets and fingers. Just tweak the mustard and honey to your taste.

Fabulous dish. I made a few minor adjustments due to lack of/other ingredients on hand. I left out the curry, instead opting for a sweet/spicy bbq rub spice I had in the pantry; added some fresh parsley on top before baking; baked at 350 for 45mins and 200-250 for 2 more hours (the chicken was so amazingly tender). Since I used boneless, skinless chicken breasts, I cut them into about 5 chunck (looked almost like little pork cutlets). Again, amazing.

userID:
1921489
Display Name:
Kristi S
isPro:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe; it turned out very good, but I did make several alterations based on reviewer suggestions. I used split rib bone-in chicken breasts with the skin, and I cut the butter to 1/4 c., although I think I may leave it out altogether next time because you really don't need it with the fat of the meat. I upped the curry powder to 1 1/2 tsp. but I think I will add more next time, and I also added a little minced garlic and 1/4 tsp. chili powder, but will probably up that too next time to give it more of a kick. I cooked it for 1 hour covered with foil at 350, turning once, then turned again and cooked uncovered at 400 for 20 minutes longer, basting a few times. This will definitely go into our regular meal rotation because it's a great way to use other less expensive chicken parts outside of the boneless, skinless breasts I normally buy, and it is so easy and delicious! I served with rice too and used the remaining sauce.

text:
My boyfriend loved this recipe!!  I only gave it 4 stars because it was a tad bit too sweet for me.  I cut back on the butter and only used 1/4 cup.  Next time I'll also cut back on honey.  I used spicy brown mustard and added a pinch of cayenne per others' suggestions. I used about 3 whole boneless skinless chicken breats. My oven was giving off fumes so at the last minute I decided to cook it on the stove.  I seared each side for 2 minutes, then poured the sauce over the chicken and cooked on low for 20 minutes.  The breasts were tender and juicy.  The ingrediants made a great flavor.

This was a big hit at my house. Read all the reviews and followed the tips. Marinating was great, as well as cutting the butter in half.  Chicken makes grease so why cook it in so much butter? I used chicken thighs and cooked with foil the first half then basted as suggested. The sauce was wonderful on rice and although I made two packs of thighs so we could have leftovers for lunch the following day, nothing was left! Excellent recipe.

None
country:
None
text:
Rates a 4.5 - very good, easy and you probably have all the ingredients in your kitchen.  **Would've been way too sweet for us with that much honey,** so I cut the honey down by half. And, as others have pointed out, you only need half the butter that the recipe calls for.  I used regular French's mustard - same amount as in the recipe; 1.5 tsp of curry instead of 1 and added 1/2 tsp. of cayenne, 1/2 c. diced yellow onion and 3 large cloves of diced garlic.  There was plenty of leftover sauce.  I cooked 4 large boneless, skinless, half-breasts. Thanks for the helpful comments and to the originator for the great recipe!

If you love curry, you’ll love this dish!  I cut the butter in half as recommended and instead of regular mustard, used dijon. I cut up a whole chicken, but next time I’ll just use chicken breasts since I don’t care for the skin. I put all of the sauce and the chicken in a dish, covered the pan with foil, and baked for 30 minutes. Then uncovered, rebasted, and cooked it for another 10 minutes. I served this over couscous.

text:
My mouth was watering as I read the reviews to this recipe, but I was somewhat disappointed. I didn't see how I was going to get that crispy golden crust everyone talked about with all those juices in the pain, I changed pan 3 times to get rid of some of the juice. I ended up pouring all the juice out and baking it about 2 hours and making more sauce and turned the oven up to 400 as someone suggested, just so I could get that golden look.  Honestly I liked the flavor, it just didn't work out like I thought. It was good though, just a lot of extra steps.  I love to cook and love trying new things.  I would cook it again just a little different next time. I don't know what I didn wrong, if anything.

country:
None
text:
The recipe was incredibly delicious! I made it using chicken legs.  The only thing I did different was I decreased the amount of butter, using 1/4 cup and cooked it for 35 min. (at 350 degrees) with tin foil over the baking dish, then upped the temperature to 400 degrees, took the cover off and cooked it for 40 min., making it a total of the 75 min.  I basted it 3 times during the time the cover was off.  I'm not a huge curry fan, but this amount was perfect!  The mixture stuck nicely on the chicken and had a nice deep dark texture.  I will be making this again, that's for sure.  I would love to try it using buffalo wings too. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
mmm, delish!  Used skinless chicken thighs, cooked uncovered at 400 for 1 hour (like it well done).  Used my deep roasting pan and didn't have any trouble with smoking/burning.  You could even place the chicken on a rack in a roasting pan so it isn't sitting in all the grease.  If you like curry I would add an extra tsp because I couldn't really taste the curry all that much.  This was super easy and very low maintenance 'set and forget it' as they say :D

text:
This is terrific and easy.  I made this before I read the reviews and I am really glad I did, because this recipe is great the way it is.  The reason you should baste instead of turning is because the skin becomes really crisp and wonderful.  The curry is extremely important and so don't exclude or substitute! It balances.  I think it probably would be okay to reduce the butter or substitute a bit of olive oil for some of the butter.  Great, and this will become a staple in my recipe box.

text:
This is a wonderful and simple chicken dish.  I've been fixing it for several years now and usually get tons of compliments!  It works equally well with cut up chicken pieces, as it does with boneless breasts or thighs.  I prefer to remove the skin from my chicken before baking, just because it's fattier than I'd like if I don't.  If I'm using chicken pieces with the skin removed, I bake the pieces top-side down so that it doesn't dry out, again, just personal preference!  I generally serve this dish with white rice, steamed broccoli, salad and crescent rolls.  So yummy!

This recipe is exceptionally easy and produces really delicious chicken.  If you cook it at 400 F, the sauce carmelizes and the chicken is really tender. The dish will make you wonder why you ever go to a restaurant. It is only passable when cooked at 350 F, so don't. There is just enough curry to give it an interesting flavor.

text:
A winner!!  I used a whole, 4-lb. cut-up Kosher chicken, and the full amount of butter (may use less next time :)).  Instead of the full amounts of honey and mustard, I used lesser amounts of Trader Joe's "Honey Pale Ale Mustard" and Trader Joe's Raw Organic Honey.  I DID cover the chicken for the first 30 mins., (as others had recommended); then uncovered and basted every 15 mins. for the remainder of time.  Even tho' the inside temp. of the chicken was around 185ºF when done,  the chicken was moist & juicy (even the breast!)  It was DELICIOUS, and the sauce was great over rice!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this with minor changes: only 2T of butter and bumped the curry powder up to 2t. Started skin side down @ 375, covered the dish in foil. Removed the foil after 30min and turned the thighs skin up, basting every 10min for 30 more minutes.

Removed the chicken to a dish and transferred the sauce to a saucepan, skimming the fat. Punched up the sauce with honey and mustard, thickened with cornstarch slurry, making a nice gravy. Served with whole roast garlic cloves on the side.

text:
I have made this several times, and agree that 1/4 cup butter is plenty. Just one note: I am a salt lover, but some curry powders have a lot of salt already! I mix it all together without any salt first, and then taste it.  One of the Madras Curry powders I have needs no salt added, but  I need to use 2 tsp. of the powder for flavor. I usually use skinless boneless cutlets,  and cover it for 30 minutes, and uncover for 20.  thicken up the sauce a bit and put it over rice. I usually serve it with a green vegetable.

text:
Excellent dish!  I added a few of the ideas in the comments but also used boneless & skinless chicken breasts. Poked holes as suggested but didn't marinate long.  Added extra teaspoon of curry powder,  1/2 teaspoon of cumin and 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder.  Cooked in Pyrex baking dish with a lid for 30 minutes,  then removed lid and cooked an additional 30 minutes.  I'd added about 1/8 cup of water to the spices so the chicken was covered and basting wasn't necessary. Chicken was delightful and tender. Definitely a repeat recipe.

country:

text:
I took this recipe to another level.  I used a rotisserie chicken. A nice big juicy one from a popular warehouse store.  I broke it down into eight pieces. I made the sauce with the only changes being decreased butter and adding a pinch of cayenne pepper.  I used a 9x 13 pan lined with foil.  The preheated oven was at 350.  I covered the pan with foil and cooked 30 min.  I increased the temp to 400, removed the foil and cooked another 30 min. basting twice.
The chicken skin caramelized and the sauce thickened.
Great recipe, good flavor and so easy.

Display Name:
BonCanCook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really easy to make and delicious. I did not use curry seasoning because I don't like the flavor.  I used 1/4 cup of butter, 1/4 cup of honey, and 1/4 cup of Dijon mustard as other reviewers suggested.  I also laid the chicken on top of sliced yellow onions.  I basted the chicken every fifteen minutes. I started the chicken skin side down and covered. After the first fifteen minutes, I turned the chicken over and then basted every fifteen minutes. I also sliced a russet potato and laid the thick slices on the baking sheet. I continued basting the chicken and potatoes every fifteen minutes.  The result is an absolutely delicious one-pan meal. Keep an eye on it towards the end of cooking time because the honey starts to carmelize and could burn.  My chicken was a little over done and looked a little like barbecue but it was honesty yummy. I would serve this to company in a minute, especially because it's inexpressive and SO EASY to prépare.   Yummy, yummy, yummy! Next time I'll make a bigger tray so that I have plenty of leftovers.
Review:

text:
First time fixing this recipe, will not be the last. I baked it at 325 in my convection oven, think next time may try 300. I went with the full recommended cooking time. The skin was more dark, internal temperature was 205, but the meat was just wonderful, falling off the bone. The dark skin had a nutty cashew flavor, but was a little chewy. I did season with salt and pepper before the first basting. 
Bottom line is this dish is wonderful!

I wish I could give this recipe 100 stars!!! I absolutely LOVE LOVE LOVE this recipe! Using chicken thighs bone in are better then boneless chicken breasts.... The bones and dark meat really enhances the flavor. I do like to make more of the sauce to dip the chicken in or have it on the rice. I will even save the sauce and use it on another meal. I've never been a huge curry fan but this recipe uses it so well that I'm so glad I tried it. Yummm yummm yummm... I don't change anything to it. It's amazing just how it is!! Give it a try!

Display Name:
Jean Monique Sanchez

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4164137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out surprisingly delicious! As suggested in reviews, I used 1/4 cup butter, 1 1/4 tsp curry powder and rest as is. Also added 1/2 tsp garlic powder. I used 4 thigh-leg quarters. Baked at 350F covered for 30 mins, turned the chicken and continued baking uncovered for another 30 mins. Turned again and then increased temp to 400F and baked for another 20 mins. There were a lot of oil so I separated the chicken from the sauce. Drained excess oil. Added some cornstarch (dissolved in water) and boiled til sauce thickened. Then poured sauce on top. Served with rice. Awesome! I will definitely make again.
Review:

None
text:
The hubs and I both loved it. I wish it were crispier though. Changes I had made on this recipe as suggested by other members were 1/3 c of mustard and honey. 2Tbs of butter. 1/2 tsp curry and 1/2tsp of masala and 1/4tsp of paprika as well as a pinch of nutmeg. I added an onion chopped into quarters and mushrooms to this recipe.

 45-50mins in the oven for 2 big pieces of breast.  broiled for the first 8-10mins with the foil on and loosely covered the rest of the time. 

The sauce that I got in the end was enough for 1 cup of rice (or 2 people) but it was thick on the chicken, which reminded me of a yogurt chicken recipe like butter masala or rogan josh kind.

Thank you for this recipe!

I used olive oil and honey mustard.  I used also boneless, skinless  chicken breasts.  I seasoned first the chicken with salt. This will be my go to recipe for baked chicken pieces.  I am giving this just 4 stars as I think this recipe can still be improved

text:
We loved this recipe, I did marinate it in the fridge for 1 hour prior to baking, next time I will take foil off after 30 min, then baste and continue to cook and brown. The drumsticks were tender and moist, and the flavor delicious. I have enough sauce left for the left overs. I served over white rice with corn bread and baked crispy zucchini,  easy recipe, will be a mainstay at our table.  Thank you. This was my first recipe from this site!
