country:
None
text:
I read quite a few of the other reviews and made the following adjustments: eliminated butter (I was using leg/thigh/back attached pieces, so lots of fat); cut salt in half; doubled curry powder; used a grainy Bavarian style mustard; added 1/2 tsp hot pepper flakes and 1/2 tsp garlic powder. That sauce was wonderful. I'll add a bit more heat next time. The family commented that no one ingredient stood out - they all married together beautifully. The sauce was wonderful on Basmati rice. Will definitely make this again.

None
country:
None
text:
I loved this! Next time I will use NO butter at all. I made this recipe but changed to 2 tsp of curry powder, added garlic paste, cut down butter to 1/4 cup (but it was still unnecessarily oily given that I used chicken thighs). I did not need to double the recipe and used it on 8 chicken thighs. Cooked at 365 degrees for 55 minutes and then set it on broil for the last 5 min. Did not use foil and did baste it every 15 min with its own juices and oil. Next time I will add onions to the bottom/sides as another reviewer suggested and put some of the sauce under the skin, too. It was so good with roasted cauliflower and orzo rice pilaf on the side! WINNER - very juicy. Thanks to all for their reviews!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So let me first off say that I love this recipe, the description,  the videos,  the reviews were all so helpful. 

Because of my busy work life I find myself having to rely on my slow cooker to complete most recipes. For this sweet/tangy/curry filled greatness I decided I'd try my hand at slow cooking to perfection. 

First I followed the sauce ingredients exactly as written (used spicy brown mustard as the video mentioned). I had about 2 lbs of boneless skinless chicken breast that needed to be cooked so I made the sauce, threw the chicken into the slow cooker, topped the chicken with the sauce, and let it cook on low for about 6 to 7 hrs. 

I like my chicken to be browned some so I decided to broil the result in the oven for able 5 or so min a side at the end.

let me tell you I love the result. And will be repeating the process for my loved ones.

country:

text:
This was great! I made it with a whole chicken (5lbs). It took an extra 15 minutes to cook. I split it up into all the seperate parts and put it in a 9x13 baking dish. Then I mixed up the honey sauce with all the ingredients. I didn't have curry so I used turmeric, cumin and made my own variation with garlic powder and onion powder. This tasted great. I reduced the butter as everyone recommended and cooked it covered for the first thirty minutes. We made short work of a whole chicken. I served it with lentils and brown rice, which were a great accompaniment for the flavor of the chicken. Even the 4 year old ate it. The adults added extra heat with Louisiana hot sauce, which was so good. We also used the juices in the 9x13 pan by spooning them onto the chicken after plating it. You have to try this!

None
text:
Great combo of flavors--even my three picky eaters loved it! My comments: use similar chicken pieces instead of whole chicken (for even cooking), breasts for quicker cooking, add sliced carrots and potatoes around chicken pieces, reduce butter (even by a half), you could spice it up more, too, with another tsp curry. Foil on for one hour, turning/basting every 15 minutes, foil off for 30 minutes, 15 minutes per side. Served on rice, which absorbed the yummy juices.

text:
Great recipe.  Made with 3  large chicken thighs as there is only my husband & myself at home.  Followed several suggestions: layer of sliced onion on the bottom of the casserole dish, 1/4 cup melted butter,  1 1/2 teaspoons curry powder, 1/8 teaspoon chili powder, 1 teaspoon paprika and fresh grated black pepper on top of the thighs (like the extra sauce, used the recipe amounts for the honey & mustard).  Covered with foil the 1st 30 minutes.  Then uncovered & basted every 15 minutes until internal temperature was at least 170.

I had two casserole dishes,
About 12 chicken thighs with skin and bones.
I doubled the recipe.
I was out of curry so I used cumin.
I added some Paprica.
After 1 hour the chicken was nice and brown.
The meat was falling off of the bones.
It was  all floating in butter and grease after cooking.
I removed the chicken immediately and put on a plate.
It was great!!!
Next time I will use boneless/skinless thighs.



It needs some red chili papers though.

text:
This was excellent! I made a few changes just for our tastes but I'm sure made as is would be fine. I used 1/4 c. Coconut oil for butter, doubled the sauce, added 8 cloves minced garlic, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, used Dijon mustard, 6 tsp curry powder and sliced a medium onion to put in the bottom of pan. I only used 3 bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs. Covered with foil for 40 minutes, turned chicken over and continued baking uncovered until chicken was done.  Used the sauce over rice and it was amazing.

userID:
6749077
Display Name:
Gigi Hunermund
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
15
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2216191.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made some changes:

Boneless skinless chicken thighs (5 large)instead of cut up chicken
2 tbl olive oil instead of butter
1/3 cup dijon mustard
1/2 cup honey
1/2 cup chicken broth
2 tsp mild yellow curry
1 tsp garam masala
2 large garlic cloves
4 med yukon gold potatoes skin on
1/2 small bag of baby carrots

I layered the chicken on top of the potatoes and carrots, poured sauce on top and baked for what seemed like forever. It took almost two hours to cook the potatoes the way I like. Next time I think I will get those small yukon gold potatoes that you microwave in the bag.  I will also blanch the thighs first.  Then I will add everything to a pan and bake. That should help to get dinner on table quicker.

I liked the suggestion to stick under the broiler for a few min at the end to get really nice color.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Nom Nom Nom!! This was DELICIOUS and definitely one of better recipes I've made from All Recipes. I tweaked the recipe a little bit to fit my needs, as I think that is appropriate for anyone to do so I am sorry if my review is not exactly based on what the original recipe called for. I usually like to read the good and bad reviews before making any recipe and use the most common tips left on there. I cut the butter in half to 1/4 cup, upped the curry to 1 tablespoon, added sliced onion, added 1/2 teaspoon garlic salt, and used chicken breast instead of a whole chicken. I also took some of the other tips on the reviews and cooked it with covered foil for the first 50 minutes, and then uncovered for the remaining time.  It was amazing! The chicken was soo juicy, and the flavor of the curry and honey mustard was just right.  It definitely tasted like an Indian dish, so if you are craving that type of meal I would recommend this as it is easy.  I also served it with brown rice and veggies, and will be making it for my family and friends to impress them ;)

text:
Really good!  I made mine with chicken thighs and took another's advice to bake it covered in foil at 350 degress for the first 30 minutes. Then foil is removed and chicken is basted, basking for another 40 minutes or so until nicely browned.  I decreased the butter to 1/3 cup and increased the curry to 2 teaspoons.  I'll definitely make this again!  Thank you!

text:
Very tasty.
On the recommendation of others I used only 1/4 cup butter (half the amount recommended) and 2 tsp curry powder (twice as much).
Next time I will use even less butter as others have done, since the chicken fat is plenty (unless you take the skin off the chicken).
I cooked this for 30 minutes covered with foil and then 45 minutes more basting a couple of times.
Overall, great place to start experimenting...honey, mustard, curry powder and butter is a great base!
Wonder if this would be even better with some crunchy celery or peppers....??? Mmm...

text:
Not a 5 star to me because the sauce lacks interest.  I made it as directed but didn't find much excitement there- perhaps more curry as others have suggested would have been better.  I used boneless skinless chicken thighs and that was a BIG disappointment both in looks and texture (didn't affect my rating though).  I think the dish will  be best if you use a whole chicken, skin and all, for a nice presentation and good mouth appeal.  And that's what the original poster intended!!!  The sauce was watery there at the last, but I drained it off, separated most of the grease, and then boiled it to thicken it.  When I poured the sauce over the chicken once more, it made a nice glaze that stayed on well.

Read some reviews and halved the butter but I also halved the honey (for the calories).  Left the quantities the same on the (coarse Dijon) mustard and the curry.  Only used 3/4 t. of salt.  It was just PERFECT for our tastes.  I put it in a 9x11 dish and the sauce was already more than half way up the sides of the chicken.  I did cover it for the first 45 minutes with foil.  Very simple and very, very good.  Thank you for such a quick and tasty dish.  This would be wonderful over brown rice.

region:

country:
None
text:
I used muuuuuch less butter (and substituted grapeseed oil for the fat as well). I also used only chicken breast and baked til they were about done, turned the oven up and let them get more golden since they were still quite pale. I also added some tarragon and white pepper for added flavor. I tasted the mixture and it definitely needed a little something else.   I marinated the chicken in the mixture over night, placed them in a baking dish, poured the remaining mixture over the breasts and let it all bake together for the entire time. This was great with rice and sliced cold into salad.

text:
I have made this recipe many times now for my DH (he loves it!).  It's a very simple yet tasty recipe.  In order to cut down on the fat, I use skinless chicken breasts and use only 1/2 the amount of butter called for in the recipe.  As others have suggested, the first 30 minutes I bake the chicken covered in foil then baste the chicken every 10 minutes until the chicken is fully cooked.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!  I had to change a few ingredients, but it was still awesome!  I used 1/4 cup of i can't believe it's not butter, a "swirl around the bowl" of olive oil, 1/2 cup of honey, 1/4 cup spicy brown mustard, no salt and 1 TBSP of curry.  I did cover it for about 35-40 minutes @ 350, then uncovered it for about 20 minutes.  There was still a bowl full of juice left, which could easily be made into a gravy, but I just put it on the table as it was and we poured it over our homemade fries....yummy!  You know when your husband tells you to keep a recipe, it's good!

text:
This came out great! I made a few changes, but nothing too major. I added a bit more curry than the recipe called for and also threw in a 1/2 a teas. of cayenne pepper because we like a little kick. I shook salt directly on the chicken rather than mixing it into the sauce.   It smelled so Indian and I was worried, because my boyfriend does not really like Indian food, but coupled with the honey, the curry was not overpowering at all, but complimented the dish wonderfully. I served it over instant mashed potatoes and it was delicious.  Honey Baked Chicken was so easy to make and very tasty. I will definitely make this again.

userID:

Display Name:
chinook50

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent flavor combination.  To reduce fat and calories I used 2 chicken breasts sliced into 1" strips, 1T olive oil, 1T honey, 1t Dijon mustard, 1t curry powder.   In a med bowl I mixed the honey, mustard and curry then added the chicken let it marinate for 30 min. Heated the oil on med in a frying pan for 3 minutes then added the chicken, cooked on med for 6 minutes each side. Then it works out to 340 calories & 15g fat per serving.
Review:

5

Delicious. I used about half the sauce and cooked a panful of boneless chicken breasts and some thighs in an oven bag. I served chunks of the tender chicken breast with a package of Green Giant Immunity blend vegetables (cauliflower, orange and yellow carrots and dried cranberries in a butter sauce) over some angel hair pasta. Great fall flavors. We loved it! With the remaining chicken breasts, I made Fruited Curry Chicken Salad by Karen L. Baker. This was also fabulous. I packed them as wraps in our lunches. I am using the thighs today to make a chicken tortilla soup.

text:
The chicken tasted great on the outside but was dry inside.  Admittedly I modified the recipe to be chicken filets that I pan seared, but just an FYI done this way they are dry.  Perhaps if I had punctured filets and marinated they would have been more moist, or if there was some acid/citrus it might have helped.  The outside did carmelize very well.

The best though was tonight I made chicken and rice soup with the leftovers. It was awesome. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read the reviews and followed other people's suggestions.  I used chicken thighs (because it's what I had), decreased the butter to 6 tablespoons, and baked it covered in tinfoil for the first hour.  It turned out wonderfully.  I served it with rice and sauted zucchini.  My S/O loved it and said that he really wants me to keep the recipe in the dinner rotation.    While it was good, I had to separate the grease from the sauce in order to have some to pour over the rice.  Next time I'll use even less butter.  Maybe 1/4 cup like other recommend.  I'll only use 1/2 the marinade at the start.  At 45 minutes, I'll drain the grease (from the fatty thighs) and put the rest of the marinade in.

text:
Tasty and very easy to make! I saved this recipe a while ago and finally tried it tonight using boneless, skinless chicken breasts each cut into thirds. I marinated the chicken in the sauce (used 1/2 the butter, no salt and honey mustard dijon) in the baking dish for about an hour, then baked it covered for 30 min., flipped chicken and baked another 15-20 minutes uncovered. I served it with yellow rice, next time I think a white rice will compliment the gravy and chicken better. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
5/14/2009 - I was kind of disappointed with this.  The chicken was nice & juicy, but I couldn't taste the glaze at all.  7/31/2011 - I was kind of in a bind for something to make tonight with chicken, so I thought I'd give this another try, since I had all the ingredients.  Changed from 3 to 5 stars, MUCH BETTER!  I used some other reviewers hints - boned, skinned chicken breasts, less butter, Dijon, garlic salt & garam masala.  I also marinated the chicken in the refrigerator for about 1-1/2 hours before baking @ 425 for 20 minutes.  Served with a green salad and cranberry-walnut bread from the wonderful French bakery not far from our house.  Would be great with basmati rice...next time, I guess.

This recipe is good, not the best I have ever had but it was good and I will be making it again. I used boneless skinless chicken breast because that is all I had and that's what I prefer. I used all the butter amount even though some people said to cut back. I didn't have curry powder we don't really like any spices and never use them. I made this up this morning and let my chicken sit in it all day. I cooked it at 350 for 30 mins with reyonlds wrap on took it off and cooked it for another 30 mins, every 15 I turned it over and poured the juice on it. The best part of it is that it didn't dry up like chicken usually does.  We had alittle left over and going to have it tomorrow.

Average rating from our family would be a 4.  I thought it was good. Don't know what I really expected of it.  I used Coarse Ground Mustard and a little less butter than it called for.  There was WAY too much sauce, I only poured half over the chicken and still only basted with what was in the pan. I used boneless/skinless breasts and pounded them to about 1/2 inch thick.  They were cooked in 30 minutes or less. Next time I try this, I will maybe use another mustard to see if I prefer it.  My picky eater ate some, My hard to please eater LOVED it and went back for 2nds, my husband enjoyed it as well. We served with rice and I actually used a tad of the pan sauce over the rice.

text:
I was so excited to try this recipe, but somewhat disappointed with the results.  It looked marvelous and smelled even better, but we found the taste very bland (even though I salt-and-peppered the chicken first), and as everyone says, way too much butter.  I also felt it needed some fresh herbs - parsley or rosemary or something - not sure yet.  Next time I will add way less butter and a bit of sriracha hot sauce to taste, and maybe use a mustard with more bite.  But all in all, a great base recipe, so my 4 stars are for potential!

text:
I gave this recipe 5 stars for several reasons.  Next week is grocery shopping week so I was going off less than normal.  First let me say that I was elated that I had everything already in my pantry to make this.  Another reason I rated it so highly was because it was soo easy.  Literally I dumped the few required ingredients in a bowl, mixed them, and poured them over the chicken.  The basting every 15 minutes was fine to me.  It didnt take more then 1 minute to open the oven and baste the chicken with the drippings.  It was ready as the recipe called for in 75 minutes.  The flavor was good and the meat was juicy and tender.  Let me just say that is isnt spicy as described here.  Which didnt bother me, I knew from looking at the ingredients that it wouldnt be spicy.  I cant believe I hadnt tried this recipe until now. I will be sharing this with my neighbors.  Thanks

I've been making this dish for a year or so now.  It is a family favorite!  It's so easy and uses so few ingredients!  It comes out perfect every single time.  I make absolutely no adjustments as it needs no improvements at all!  It's so sweet and savory and the skin is perfectly crispy!  This is the first review I've ever done and I've been using this site for years.  I guess that says something!!

Ok so years later I am STILL making this dish.  So easy and so good.  Some risotto or couscous and some veggies and such an easy delicious meal.  I have, however, changed to a lower fat diet and I found all I have to do is reduce the butter - even significantly, and its JUST as good.    I substitute a little olive oil and you'd never know the difference.  This has been a keeper for years.

text:
This is a very easy way to spruce up baked chicken.  I would, however, reduce the amount of butter used here.  I used less butter than listed in the recipe and even so, it was very buttery.  Also, you don't need to add salt (assuming your butter is salted).  I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs so reduced the baking time by about 15-20 minutes or so.  Next time I'll use this with skin-on chicken - I know it will brown and carmelize nicely.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really yummy marinade that both my boyfriend and I enjoyed. I followed it pretty much to a T, but instead of a whole chicken, I used about 2 lbs of boneless/skinless chicken breast that I cut into pieces, and I cooked it my own way. I forked holes in each piece and coated them with the marinade in a glass pan. After I refrigerated it for an hour or 2, I cooked them in a pan w/olive oil and some black pepper, didn't take long at all to cook through and give them a golden color. They turned out to be these really tasty honey mustard medallions w/a hint of curry flavor. I'll make it again.

None
text:
Very good. Was told to put this on the permanent rotation! Used skinless, boneless chicken breasts, way less butter (actually used benecol), upped the curry. shook in a little onion and garlic powder and a dash of cayenne. Mixed the honey and the rest of the mixture right in my casserole dish. Didn't have too much time so put the oven up to 400 degrees - 15 minutes covered with foil and then 15 minutes uncovered. My basting was just flipping the chicken after the first 15 minutes. Served it with basmati rice and a mixture of veggies. Super easy and super good.

This was delicious! I altered the recipe based on other reviewers' comments, using 1/2c honey, 1/3c mustard & 1/4c butter, no salt, 2t curry powder and 1t cayenne powder. I turned chicken ~3 times, keeping the dish covered for the first 30 minutes. Next time I'd bake it for a little less time so the chicken stays more moist. Served over basmati rice is perfect!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This makes it into my March Menu! Notes: If I make this again I will use only 1/3 cup butter. I will increase the mustard to 1/3 cup and use a sweet hot mustard. I will increase the curry to 1.5-2 tsp and add 1/2 tsp of hot sauce. These are our personal preferences as a family. We like everything to have a bit of a kick to it.  Also, since my oven is on the fritz, I baked this for only 25 minutes in my Advantium 240 at 7, 4 & 2. (If you don't know what an Advantium is email me and I will tell you, or look it up on the web.)I would hate to be without mine. I have to watch it more carefully as the skin blackened some. Next time the upper lights can be turned down to about 4-5. Although, the breasts I cooked were HUGE. They were bone-in and over a pound each. Smaller breasts would clearly cook in a shorter time in the Advantium. Maybe 20 minutes. Either way, I can't complain about a yummy chicken and rice dinner on the table in less than 30 minutes. Thanks for a great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
2811251
Display Name:
BPS
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
16
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2789280.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this chicken for dinner on Valentines.  It was fabulous!!!  I took a few of the reviewers tips and only used 1/4 cup butter, I can't imagine using 1/2 cup, it would be too watery and greasy.  I also added 1/8 tsp of cayenne pepper and 1 minced clove of garlic.  I used 1 1/2 tsps of curry powder, not just 1 tsp.  Instead of a whole chicken I would recommend using chicken breasts and I would suggest marinating the chicken in the mix over night.  I did this and when we ate, all the seasonings seemed to permeate the the chicken making it VERY moist and we could taste all the wonderful flavors throughout.  I cooked the chicken covered for 35 minutes and then uncovered for 40 minutes, basting every 10 minutes.  This recipe was a huge hit with my Valentine, he loved it and asked me to make it again for him!  Thank you Gretchen Ramey, you helped to make my Valentines dinner truly special.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-02-14T18:55:18.487

userID:
1203483
Display Name:
Fujiko

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good. Per suggestions of other reviewers, I cut the butter back to 1/4 cup. I used four boneless, skinless chicken breasts. I also doubled the amt of curry (I love curry). I threw in a dash of ceyenne pepper. I also sliced about a half of a white onion up and placed the slices on top of the chicken. I used a leave-in meat thermometer and the chicken got to 165 degrees in a half hour, while covered. At this point I uncovered and baked for about 15 minutes longer. Next time I will reduce the amt of honey, as it was a bit too strong of a flavor. I think I will also increase the amt of ground red pepper and maybe add a few other spices.

userID:
1307857
Display Name:
glo
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
42
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/51057.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe... made a few alterations and everyone asked for the recipe! Used 7lbs of boneless/skinless chicken breast cut up in bite sized pieces, used only a few Tbsp of butter, added a Tbsp of country dijon mustard, 1/8 tsp of cayenne pepper, 2 minced cloves of garlic, and a bit of garlic salt.  Only baked it for 40 minutes and it was done! Left the foil on for the whole cooking time.  Served with brown rice, was a nice complement b/c it soaked up the flavorful juices. The juices were really runny-- my chicken was in a pool of juices. Next time, I will try mixing a little cornstarch or flour with the juices in a saucepan to thicken it up. I noticed in the leftovers the juices thickened up just from sitting, so you might want to make it the day before.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-02-10T22:04:28.223

text:
I've tried this recipe 3 times, and each time it's been great. I followed some of the modifications of others: 1/4 cup of butter (I can't imagine how oily 1/2 cup would make it because it's already a calorie-loaded dish), a dash more curry, a little cayenne pepper (1/8 tbsp), and some garlic. At first I was a little afraid of how it would look once its cooked because in some pics the chicken still looked uncooked, but after an hour I take the foil off the top and brown it for about 30 mins, and it comes out a beautiful golden brown.

text:
This is a good recipe. The cooking time given is too long though. My oven is gas and is also very accurate as most People's ovens are not. So be careful with your cooking time. Get an oven thermometer at the store! They are cheap! The only changes I made to this recipe was to simmer the honey mixture for a few minutes before putting on the chicken. I used legs and even with opening the door every 15 minutes, they were done in 45. I will be using this recipe for a whole stuffed and roasted chicken soon possibly with some sage added to it. It needs a bit more salt or some other spice. I can't put my finger on what it is though. Otherwise I would have given it a 5.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/164381.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Got a whole chicken and cut it up (difficult - I'll need to brush up on the technique on the site). Came out VERY well - son gave it a 4.5 - loved it! Will do again. Should have put foil over the pieces for a period as stated by someone else - came out a little too baked. 2nd attempt - used 1/2 butter called for - was more than enough. Used foil for 1st 30 min, took it off and basted every 15 min for next 45 min. Came out perfect. Might suggest - if people do not eat the skin, (health concerns), than skinless breasts might be better because all the good sauce/flavor is on the skin - remove the skin on the plate and you lose the majority of this great sauce's flavour. Might even poke holes in the meat prior to cooking to allow the sauce to seep into the flesh.

I found this recipe yesterday and used it last night to cook some boneless chicken thighs! It was excellent! I liked the taste and how easy it was to make.  The sauce is pretty thin.  But it was great to serve over rice.  But I did follow the one person's advice about changing the cooking time and temp to 400 degrees for 40 minutes. I thought cinnamon would go well with the honey.

text:
Was looking for something different....but easy, and this is it!  I did make a few changes, I used boneless skinless chicken breasts, and I halfed them, I didn't alter any of the other ingredients though.  I also cooked mine in a cast iron skillet and it browned nicely on 400 degrees for about an hour.  The only change I would make next time would be definitely half the butter to 1/4 cup, not only because of the fat content, but it was just too much for 4 chicken breasts.  It was very, very tender, a great flavor combination & like everyone else said....your entire house smells wonderful.  Even my 9 year old couldn't wait for supper!

This recipe was easy and wonderful tasting! I used a Whole Grain Mustard with Garlic (because that's what I had) and it was great.
